title: Diagnostic yield of clinical exome sequencing in patients with suspected hereditary neuropathy
reasoning_research: The study presents a clear clinical cohort and diagnostic pipeline, but the sample size is small (n=21) and the methodology is descriptive without experimental manipulation or computational modeling. The reliance on standard clinical guidelines (ACMG) and commercial software provides a baseline of rigor, but there is no mention of preregistration, control groups, or robustness checks beyond standard clinical reporting.
reasoning_impact: The findings are relevant to clinical genetics and diagnostic neurology, but they have minimal direct relevance to the core topics of decision neuroscience, such as self-control, attention, or computational models of choice. The implications are confined to improving diagnostic yield in hereditary neuropathies, with no stated connection to decision-making processes or theoretical advances in psychology.
